title: Can you cross out writing on a letter address? - Quora

response.answer_text: I keep Wite-Out correction tape handy for these situations. It’s the best way to be sure that the writing to be deleted won’t confuse the OCR device or the mail carrier. Or me. OCR has come a long way, but it’s still helpful to print legibly. USPS mail carriers would love for all of us to improve our printing. USPS Postal Explorer/Delivery Address requests… Always put the address and the postage on the same side of your mailpiece.On a letter, the address should be parallel to the longest side.All capital lettersNo punctuationAt least 10-point typeOne space between city and stateTwo spaces between state and ZIP CodeSimple type fontsLeft justifiedBlack ink on white or light paperNo reverse type (white printing on a black background)If you are using address labels, make sure you don't cut off any important information. Also make sure your labels are on straight. Mail processing machines have trouble reading crooked or slanted information.Okay. So, this is funny. The same site’s example violates #3, #4, & #7. And since when do we not put a comma between the city and state when they are written on the same line?  from the (Welcome | Postal Explorer) webpage

It’s not going to be a real problem in most practical cases (unless the crossing-out is messy). But the post office workers don’t like it (obviously) and the counter staff will ask you to clean it up (which was usual in my day). The point is to keep the envelope in as clean a state as possible. That is why address labels are used — so that wrong addressing can be ‘corrected’ with an overlay label. Update:— Be considerate of the postal workers. They can’t always read your handwriting. Don’t make it harder for them to do their jobs. They start at 2am or 3am and finish around lunchtime.

If the address is on the envelop, best you black it out -obscure it as much as possible. Reason (in the US, anyway): addresses are read by an automatic sorter which is actually capable of discerning many different kinds of hand writing. If you merely cross out the incorrect material, the OCR may still try to read it. And who knows where it might end up? However, if you completely black it out, there is “nothing” to read and the OR will work only on what is obviously written material. Hope that helps.

I wouldn’t. Instead try white out or securely putting a new label/adhesive on top and rewriting it there This is because the postal service or a package service doesn’t have a lot of time to read your address and get it going
